Award.AwardTitle: Improving scientific reasoning and metacognition via a conceptual physics course

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers at Carolina Coastal University are developing a new course and curricular materials that explicitly target scientific reasoning and metacognition within a conceptual physics context. The main goals of this project are: (1) to improve scientific reasoning, preparing non-STEM students to be effective citizen leaders and developing underprepared physics majors into reasonably competent science students ready for the rigors of an intense program of study; and (2) to change student's views about science and knowledge construction from a positivist-oriented view, where they regard science as an existing body of knowledge, to a more constructivist-oriented view, where acquisition of new knowledge is a creative endeavor requiring a variety of epistemological resources.

One novel and potentially transformative aspect of this project is the attention paid to issues surrounding student learning for two wildly disparate (at least by surface appearances) groups of students---the non-STEM major and the first-semester physics major. The investigators have shown significant insight in recognizing that these two groups have similar educational needs; lessons learned from both groups, and perhaps from interactions between the groups, will be of great interest to the larger physics and scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed a guided-inquiry-based course structure where the student progresses through content beginning with mostly descriptive and ending with theoretical constructs. In this project, we have adapted research-verified curricular materials for our audience and focus, and have verified the efficacy of these reforms. We have also developmed new curricular materials that explicitly target scientific reasoning and metacognition within a conceptual physics context. The main goals of this project were:

(1) to improve scientific reasoning, preparing non-STEM students to be effective citizen leaders and developing underprepared physics majors into reasonably competent science students ready for the rigors of an intense program of study; and

(2) to change student’s views about science and knowledge construction from a positivist-oriented view, where they regard science as an existing body of knowledge, to a more constructivist-oriented view, where acquisition of new knowledge is a creative endeavor requiring a variety of epistemological resources.

Incorportion of explicit reasoning activities within the courses reformed in this project have resulted in significant learning gains as measured by the Lawson's Classroom Test of Scientific Reasoning (LCTSR). This is important, since traditional physics courses have been shown to produce no measurable gain on the LCTSR, and incoming students into our program and similar programs throughout the world demonstrate scientific reasoning abilities below "formal," impacting their learning potential in science programs.

This project has resulted in 12 publications either published are in process. Included in these publications is two books to be published in 2017 and 2018 on teaching and assessing science practice and reasoning. These books are aimed at primary and secondary teachers, are based on the research completed for this project, and focus explicitly on working within the Next Generation Science Standards.
